stories.text:
Context: I'm 28yo manual QA Engineer in need to advance my skills. I don't see automation testing as the next step, but as something complementary. I've been dabbling with tech since I was 13yo and creating phpBB forums and Wordpress Sites and whatnot. I've never learned to program properly, besides improvisations and code editing in front-end projects, because I always thought of myself as being too stupid to do so + growing up in an ex communist country where you were not encouraged to learn by yourself, and you were labelled from a young age as being bright, average or dumb. Thus I've developed inefficient learning processes, biases about myself and a habit to abandon every learning path I took besides Medical Engineering. I sticked to ME due to the support I had from my very bright colleagues who didn't give up on me and taught me stuff without making me feel bad for not knowing it beforehand - an obvious thing which I didn't realise, my therapist said I might be on the autism spectrum. That's when my thirst for tech and learning went nuts, but I didn't manage to overcome the aforementioned learning deficiencies. I'm capable of understanding stuff fast if I don't feel that stuff as a burden or a test. I realised I have a phobia o tests. All my dev friends suggested me at one point or another that I would be a good fit for development, but they've also suggested I am also capable to find my own learning path and/or gave ambiguous advice which my thick brain couldn't discern.

Currently I need to learn Java/Kotlin for my current job. Obviously I'm lacking basic CS knowledge but I'm comfortable with crappy tutorials or terminals. And not afraid of any complex thing. I'm just incredibly confused; basically I don't even know what I don't know about where to start given my current condition.

I was thinking about pretending to forget everything I know, this strategy helped me pass 3 ISTQB certifications in 10 months from the first try, but it took a great amount of energy to not let personal experience influence the learning process or exam questions interpretations.

Where would I need to start? there are basic CS courses on Coursera for example, but the offer is too big and thus confusing. Does basic CS come with a trimmed down version of OOP or should that be done completely separately? should I start with a scripting language like Python and learn about OOP with it as well?

How would you do it if you were me + my current circumstances?

Any input, be it even negative, is better than no input. Sorry for this soup of ideas, I'm confused by it as well daily.
stories.title: Engineers, what path of learning CS would you take today?

stories.text: I am increasing my rate. Haven't done so in years. Client is going to be shocked. Project manager said "as long as you can justify it". I could just say "inflation", but I think he means that I link to some published rate metrics. I did some googling and only found an IEEE rate guide - which costs $45. Anyone have some resources to share?
stories.title: Ask HN: Budget season. How to justify rate?
